skill.name: Writing Hookify Rules
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a hookify rule", "write a hook rule", "configure hookify", "add a hookify rule", or needs guidance on hookify rule syntax and patterns.
skill.summary: This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a hookify rule", "write a hook rule", "confi...

security_audit.summary: Official skill from Anthropic with documented guidance only. No executable code or external integrations are present.

content.value_statement: You need clear rules that catch risky actions without false alarms. This skill teaches correct Hookify syntax, patterns, and messages.
actual_capabilities: Explain rule file structure and required frontmatter fields
Describe event types and matching fields for bash, file, stop, and prompt
Provide simple and multi condition rule examples
Offer regex tips, escapes, and common pitfalls
Define rule location, naming, and gitignore guidance
limitations: Does not execute or validate rules
Examples may need project specific tuning

use_cases.title: Standardize team guardrails
use_cases.description: Define shared Hookify rules to enforce coding and deployment checks across projects.

use_cases.title: Catch risky commands
use_cases.description: Write bash and file rules that flag destructive commands and sensitive edits.

use_cases.title: Reduce noisy patterns
use_cases.description: Tune regex patterns to reduce false positives while keeping helpful warnings.

prompt_templates.title: Start a simple rule
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Hookify rule that warns on rm -rf and explain the message text to include.

prompt_templates.title: Target file edits
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a file event rule that warns when console.log is added to TypeScript files.

prompt_templates.title: Use multi conditions
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a rule with conditions that warns when API keys are added to .env files.

prompt_templates.title: Add a stop checklist
prompt_templates.prompt: Draft a stop event rule that reminds me to run tests and update docs before finishing.

output_examples.input: Write a rule that blocks chmod 777 commands
output: Rule name uses a verb and kebab case
Event set to bash with a regex for chmod 777
Action set to block with a clear warning message

best_practices: Use specific regex patterns with proper escaping
Match the correct event and field for the tool
Write messages that explain risk and next steps
anti_patterns: Use overly broad patterns like log

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude and Codex?
faq.answer: Yes, it documents Hookify rules used with Claude Code and related workflows.

faq.question: What are the limits of the guidance?
faq.answer: It explains syntax and patterns but does not test or enforce rules.

faq.question: How do I integrate the rules?
faq.answer: Save rules as .claude/hookify.name.local.md in your project.

faq.question: Does it handle my data?
faq.answer: No, it only provides instructions and does not access your files.

faq.question: Why is my rule not triggering?
faq.answer: Check event type, field, regex escapes, and enabled status.

faq.question: How does it compare to generic regex help?
faq.answer: It focuses on Hookify fields, events, and file placement.
